history.content:
No one can tell you when to take the R1B/AC course, since that depends on what those courses actually are. Easiest AC courses are generally easier than the easiest R1Bs (R&C is always a similar degree of reading and writing, but there are some pretty darn easy ACs). 

Since you are required to take your R1B before your sophomore year ends but have no such deadline for your AC/breadths, I'd take the r1B first. It's probably ok to phase 2 CS 70 and CS 61C, but since you need CS70 to declare, I wouldn't risk that--just phase 2 your breadth or your r1B whatever it ends up being.

children.subject: In addition to the answer above, I'd say that 70 comes with a learning curve especially if you haven't been introduced to linear algebra before 16A. I don't know if that applies to you, but keep the potentially-heightened workload in mind when deciding where to place your R1B, especially because a number of R1B classes themselves require a decent amount of work.

history.content:
Hi, I'm thinking about classes for next year and have come up with the following schedule:

Fall 2020:
EE16A
CS 70
UGBA 10
and an AC+Art breath

Spring 2020:
CS61C
EE16B
Stat 20
R1B

So my question is, should I take the R1B in fall or spring (same with the AC+Art breath)? In addition, is it safe to phase 2 CS 70 and CS 61C? For context i'm currently a freshman in L&S. Thank you so much for your help.
history.subject: Schedule Help
